text: Hello, guys. We have a game which depends from push notifications aka, game start notification, game end notification, you are the winner and so on. The problem is that sometimes there is a delay and the user in these cases always loses. We also considered implementing the notifications with sockets but as I understand if the app is in background they won’t come. What can we do in this case?
keep a service running and use that to display the notification?
yes, but if the app is in background mode or killed  the web socket won’t work
well services run in background without issue
but If the app has been killed, it won’t work
ok - AS is giving me a NoClassDefFoundError when running my unit tests, but they run normally on command line
tried the good ol’ daily clean cache+restart+clean+rebuild?
probably Gradle still feeling sick after being force fed kotlin
have you tried buying a new machine?
nah, takes too damn long to get anything bought here
<@U053PPGDC>: also have some issues with unit tests in new AS
ok I’ll just wait for them to fix the g’damn ide
and run my tests in cmd
pass by reference your cup is somehow lined with orange
<@U053PPGDC>: ofc, just needed to kick the can a bit
yeah but not the proper unit tests, I’m actually running the gradle testDebugUnitTest
and it’s actually picking them up right
tooling is shit, but at least it’s improving
<@U053PPGDC>: are you running Timber? sometimes the timber lint jar (and some others) does not get deleted with an AS clean halting the whole clean process. Try to manually delete the build folder
I was getting errors because of that
<@U0B8R3VV4>: thanks for your answer, but yeah, I agree with just boolean, but it should cancel the request
this app was written pre-timber and we have our own logger impl
lol our app has timber as of yesterday as <@U07DEGHHT> said he couldn’t write another TAG.
I guess. It doesn’t bother me either way.

<@U053LEHJN>: yes you can override. That is how you replace dependencies for testing. For production though I wouldn't suggest it as I can see it leading to confusing code
<@U09T8SFG8>: another question: Do I have to keep a reference to the components in a member
The main thing to get around with dagger is that you are fully responsible in managing the lifecycle of your components
So an app component would be a member in the app class because you care for it to remain alive for forever
But for an activity component I don't keep it anywhere because when the activity is destroyed, then all the references will go with it
okay, but an activity component would not be built in the app class?
I keep it in a session manager class
An activity component would use the application component so that it can have access to its exposed dependencies but it should be created in the Activity
Just imagine the component as a huge holder of all the references related to the current screen / feature
If it stays in memory , then everything stays with it
I'll post when I'm at work some articles that were fairly good with that concept
